results.title: Age before beauty
results.creator_credit: Sarah Gibson, Susan Lambert and Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative
results.brief_description: Shows older women involved in a variety of activities including exercise classes and dances. Shows them undertaking “alternative” health treatments such as chiropractry and acupuncture. Exposes the negative stereotyping of older women and investigates women’s fear of the aging process.

results.title: What's a good book?: selecting books for children
results.creator_credit: Joanna Foster and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Various librarians and writers give their opinions as to what constitutes good reading material for children. Shows the decision-making process behind the selection of books for children’s libraries and stresses the need to consider why children like particular books. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.
results.title_for_label: What’s a good book?: selecting books for children

results.title: A Story, a story
results.creator_credit: Gail E. Hailey, Morton Schindel, Kratky Film and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Nyame, the Sky God, demands a high price in exchange for his treasure. How Ananse paid the price is told in narration and woodcuts capturing the flavour of African languages, customs and lifestyles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gail E. Hailey, Morton Schindel, Kratky Film and Weston Woods Studios

results.title: Sendak
results.brief_description: This is a rare look into the private world of Maurice Sendak, who describes the significant events of his own life and their impact on his work. Who are the monsters in “Where the Wild Things Are”? Why does everything good happen while children are asleep? How did the Lindberg kidnapping affect the fantasy of “Outside, Over There”? What influence did the personal tragedy of the Holocaust have on the characterisations Sendak has created?

results.title: Pleasure Domes
results.creator_credit: Maggie Fooke and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Is Cannes really like St Kilda, or is it just a state of mind? Animated watercolour drawings and handcoloured photocopies of photographs shape this introspective reflection on the nature of landscape and the human response to it. Technically impressive, atmospherically scored and quite hypnotic in its effect, this is a very distinguished work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maggie Fooke and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: Name your poison (Captioned)
results.brief_description: The Tibaldi brothers add a light-hearted touch to the problem of alcohol. It covers reasons for drinking - boredom, rebellion, adult role models, peer pressure and the media - and looks at how some young people have developed a responsible attitude. An excellent discussion starter for young people about the use and abuse of alcohol.
results.description: The Tibaldi brothers add a light-hearted touch to the problem of alcohol. results.title: Solving the problem
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Improving Performance”.
The final step in the process of performance appraisal is reaching a solution relevant to the problem and its cause which involves considering realistic options, agreeing on a clear action plan and setting a review date to ensure the plan is working.

results.title: Ian's case
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Improving Performance”.
Ian works in an art department. His work has become sloppy, he makes long personal phone calls, he drinks and he is constantly late or off work. His supervisor, Hugo, has spoken to him twice previously and now adopts the hard approach. Peter Quarry then assumes the role of supervisor and uses the 3 step approach.
